utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What brings you in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, so uh I'm just bringing my son uh here to the clinic. He's been having um just I think he's been complaining of uh ear ache in his uh I think it's mainly in his left ear for the last, I'd say at least a week. Um he's been kind of just having discomfort um and over the last few days uh he also started crying because of how much pain he is having, and then um we also noticed that he had like was just feeling warm, so we took his temperature and he actually had a fever just yesterday of like 39 degrees Celsius.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, uhm, alright. So let's back up just a little bit. The ear pain, when did that start? You said a couple of days ago, so was that two, three, four days?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh I think the discomfort like uh, we saw him scratching his ear for the whole last week, but uh the crying actually started just I would say four days ago, um.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So I think the last few days have been really tough for him.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, so three, four days. OK, have you taken a look into his ear? Like does does it seem red? Is there discharge?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh I think we did see some uh, just like it wasn't red or anything, but I think we did uh see some um just kind of clear to almost uh clear to yellowish fluid from his affected ear.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, clear to, you said white-ish?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh like it was a bit of a yellow tinge to to it as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yellow, OK, OK. And which ear was it, sorry, the right or left?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Left ear.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Left ear, OK. And the right ear looks normal?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, right ear, he hasn't been complaining uh at all. I haven't even looked at the right ear yet.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, is he itching his ears at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh he was he was itching like pretty much this whole week, but I think right now he's hesitant to even touch his ears.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and does it look like it's angry on the outside or on the inside of his ears?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I can't really see anything on the outside.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, and have you noticed that his hearing has changed at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um he still like answers to us and like I don't think his ear, hearing is affected.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Has he had any past issues with his ears, like ear infections or like hearing issues in the past?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no hearing issues, but he did have uh like he used to, probably when he was uh like 2 years old, he did have a couple ear infections.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK. Were they were they treated with antibiotics?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh I think one time they were, but I I'm pretty sure that was on, in his right ear.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK. He's never had to get like tubes inserted or anything like that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. Um, alright. Um has he had a stuffy nose or runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh not this week, but he he was a bit like stuffy like last week I would say.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, he was a bit stuffy, you said?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, maybe even, maybe two weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And that stopped. Did he have anything else along with his stuffy nose at that point?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing else.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um right now, have you noticed any changes in his vision, in his smell or taste?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh mo, not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about weight loss?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, he's been um growing pretty well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and you said um you had taken his temperature. When did you take his temperature?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I just took it yesterday but uh he was feeling a bit warm yesterday so we just took it and it was like um 39 degrees Celsius.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK sweet. Um so 39 degrees, so he does have a fever uh for sure. We'll take his temperature again today just to make sure. Have you been giving him anything for his high temperature, like Tylenol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, we haven't given him anything.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Have you noticed any rashes on him?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, um how about coughing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, he hasn't been really coughing.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No coughing, how about wheezing or shortness of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Like anything that would indicate he has chest pain or palpitations of his heart?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. Any dizziness or fainting spells?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Confusion?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Headaches?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how how have his bowel movements been?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: His bowel movements have been pretty much the same, um he's uh, yeah, there's been no real changes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. Um alright, and how about uh nausea or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, no, no nausea or vomiting.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any appetite change?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, uh, maybe a little bit more fussy just, but I don't know if that's probably due to the pain.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Um and how about his urine?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh his urine has been the same, like no changes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No changes, OK good. Is he an otherwise healthy kid or does he have any longstanding conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, he's pretty healthy. There have been no concerns at all that we've had for the doctor. Uh he's been growing well, um meeting all of his milestones. Um yeah, no, nothing that's concerning.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um do you know if his mother's pregnancy with him was normal? Did she have any complications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um she didn't have any like complications during the pregnancy. Uh they did have to, um I forgot what it's called, but uh he was like a difficult baby coming out. Um and he was at term though, he wasn't premature, but they had to use just um some tools to get him out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK. Um so it was a vaginal delivery, but they used some tools like forceps maybe or vacuum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah it was forceps, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK. Um and he's, you mentioned he was full term?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, he was born at uh 40 weeks.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, perfect. Did he need to be hospitalized for any reason after that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, he wasn't hospitalized. Uh we stayed there maybe one day extra just because um there was some just kind of misshaping of his head.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: That kind of went away.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, good. And is he on any medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, no medications.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No medications, up to date with his immunizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, he's all up to date.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any allergies?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um not that we know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about family history of lung conditions, heart conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no, we've been pretty healthy as parents. Um and I think my my father has like high blood pressure, diabetes, and all those types of things.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, any um ear issues like congenital ear, sorry um, genetic hearing issues or ear issues?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um does anyone at home smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no one smokes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Um and who does he live with?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So he lives with um me, his father, and his mother as well.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Uhm, any siblings?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No siblings, he's an only child.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how are things at home, um is like, are things financially stable? Any relationship issues?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, we've been pretty uh fortunate like it it's, no financial issues uh and we have a lot of support from our parents as well. Uh the relationship is great, so no, no issues.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good good. Um has he had any sick contacts recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um I don't think so. He's, we've been at home so I don't know. We we did have like, with our with my brother's uh kids like uh they came to see us once um but that was like, that was, I think at like three weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, three weeks ago. Alright, um travel to anywhere recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: No, OK. Alright, those were all the questions I had for you today. Do you have any questions that you wanted to ask me today before we end the interview?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh no, not really. Just wanted to know if, like I remember he did need antibiotics before so I was just wondering if he needs them now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, um so, well first, because some of his symptoms overlap with Covid, like the fever especially, we'll do a swab on him anyways um and you should hear those results in about 24 to 48 hours. Um and then it, this picture sounds like acute otitis media, so like an ear infection. And um it's especially likely because he's had them in the past, so I'm gonna have to take a look into his ears first before like um coming up with a management plan. But I'll kind of walk you through what we look at. So if I take a look and I see like a perforated tympanic membrane with like pus, we'd prescribe like 10 days of um antibiotics. If he has some like middle ear effusion, so like some fluids with like a bulging tympanic membrane and he appears to be really ill, uh which from the sounds of it, he sounds ill, he's had this fever for more than two days, we'll also prescribe antibiotics for 10 days. And then, if it's just some middle ear effusion, so just that clear fluid um or just the bulging tympanic membrane, we can just um reassess him in 24 to 48 hours to see how he's doing. And if he's worse, again, we'll prescribing prescribe him some antibiotics. Um the antibiotics that we usually prescribe are amoxicillin, and because he doesn't have a penicillin allergy, that should work.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, how does that sound?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: That sounds good. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
